# Elite Biglaw Firms Now Offering $500K In Signing Bonuses To Supreme Court Clerks
## Which firms are throwing half a million dollars in bonuses at former SCOTUS clerks?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 26, 2024 at 1:13 PMJanuary 26, 2024 at 11:58 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/elite-biglaw-firms-now-offering-500k-in-signing-bonuses-to-supreme-court-clerks/&text=Elite%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Now%20Offering%20$500K%20In%20Signing%20Bonuses%20To%20Supreme%20Court%20Clerks)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/elite-biglaw-firms-now-offering-500k-in-signing-bonuses-to-supreme-court-clerks/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/elite-biglaw-firms-now-offering-500k-in-signing-bonuses-to-supreme-court-clerks/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Just how much is a former Supreme Court clerk worth? How much are Biglaw firms and prestigious boutiques willing to pay to woo associates with supreme intellect and inside insights about how the nation’s highest court operates and how certain justices think? Back in 2021, we [reported](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/elite-biglaw-firms-likely-to-offer-450k-in-signing-bonuses-to-supreme-court-clerks/) that $450,000 was the forecasted rate for signing bonuses for former Supreme Court clerks. Yes, you read that correctly: former SCOTUS clerks were making almost double their Supreme bosses’ salaries in bonus money just for signing on the dotted line, on top of their base salaries and regular bonuses.

Several firms that are considered heavy hitters when it comes to wooing SCOTUS clerks — off hand, we’re talking about firms like Jones Day, Kirkland & Ellis, Gibson Dunn, and Susman Godfrey, just to name a few — have offered big-time bonuses (i.e., $400K+) to their SCOTUS clerk recruits in the past. Fast forward to 2024, where first-year salaries for associates have climbed to $225,000, and high court clerks now cost an even prettier penny.

According to the [Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/01/25/supreme-court-clerks-bonuses-law-firms/), firms are opening the coffers wide for associates fresh off a high court clerkship. Here are some of the details:

During the courting process, the city’s top law firms treat this elite group of lawyers to perks like an expensive dinner at the Wharf or Penn Quarter or a trip to a baseball game or spa. The recruitment is so competitive that signing bonuses for Supreme Court law clerks have reached a new high — $500,000, according to a spokeswoman for law firm Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher.

Wow! Supreme Court clerks are now worth half a million dollars on a Biglaw market, which is an absolutely mind-blowing amount. Talk about some golden handcuffs! But if that’s the going rate for legal superstars, you can bet that Biglaw firms are going to happily pay for it.

As noted by the Post, Jones Day continues to corner the market on Supreme Court clerks, having hired 22 clerks since October Term 2020, while Gibson Dunn and Kirkland & Ellis follow behind, with 12 clerks and eight clerks each. These firms are shelling out a ton of cash to hire the very best — and it leaves us wondering if other firms are willing to follow in their footsteps.

If you know that your firm is paying $500,000 or more for SCOTUS clerks, [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=SCOTUS%20Clerkship%20Bonuses) (subject line: “SCOTUS Clerkship Bonuses”) or text us (646-820-8477), and we’ll compile a list of every firm that’s paying so generously for supreme talent.

[Clerks for hire: The Supreme Court recruiting race](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/01/25/supreme-court-clerks-bonuses-law-firms/) [Washington Post]

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

## * Former Attorney General Eric Holder headed to Iowa earlier this week, but claims that he's still deciding whether or not he's going to throw his hat into the already crowded ring for the 2020 Democractic presidential nomination. [[NPR](https://www.npr.org/2019/02/12/677956774/former-attorney-general-eric-holder-close-to-2020-decision-as-he-heads-to-iowa)] * Michael Cohen was supposed to appear before the Senate Intelligence Committee yesterday, but his testimony was postponed for the third time this month, this time "due to post surgery medical needs." What's he getting done before jail? [[CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2019/02/11/politics/michael-cohen-postpones-congressional-testimony/index.html)] * In the “mommy track” class-action lawsuit that was filed against Morrison & Foerster, the firm isn’t now claiming that its positive track record for supporting women and working parents contradicts claims that MoFo is actually discriminating against mothers and pregnant women behind closed doors. [[The Recorder](https://www.law.com/2019/02/12/in-mommy-track-lawsuit-mofo-points-to-its-track-record-for-defense/)] * It is possible to survive -- and even thrive -- in Biglaw while living with depression and other mental health disabilities. Mark Goldstein, counsel at Reed Smith, tells the tale of how his firm supported him through it all with open arms. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2019/02/12/scared-ashamed-crippled-how-one-lawyer-overcame-living-with-depression-in-big-law/)] * Jones Day has once again been named by Acritas as the best law firm brand in the country. The firm was "proud" to take the top spot, but other firms like Skadden, which came in second place this year, are busy "catching up." [[Big Law Business](https://biglawbusiness.com/jones-day-once-again-named-top-u-s-law-firm-brand-in-survey)] * Carmel Prashker Ebb, the first woman to clerk for a federal appellate judge, RIP. [[ABA Journal](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/first-female-clerk-to-a-federal-appeals-judge-dies-at-the-age-of-94)]

# Am Law 100: What Does It Mean For Those On The Job Hunt?
## The Am Law 100 provides a valuable service for those who seek to make an informed employment decision.
By [Nicholas Alexiou](https://abovethelaw.com/author/nalexiou/)  
onApril 26, 2019 at 9:59 AMApril 26, 2019 at 11:05 AM
108
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/am-law-100-what-does-it-mean-for-those-on-the-job-hunt/&text=Am%20Law%20100:%20What%20Does%20It%20Mean%20For%20Those%20On%20The%20Job%20Hunt?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/am-law-100-what-does-it-mean-for-those-on-the-job-hunt/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/am-law-100-what-does-it-mean-for-those-on-the-job-hunt/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In case it was not obvious from the flurry of press releases that flooded inboxes earlier this week, on Tuesday, The American Lawyer released the [2019 Am Law 100](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/04/23/the-2019-am-law-100-by-the-numbers/).  This yearly thorough examination and ranking of Biglaw financials provides a chance for many firms to crow about record-breaking revenues while others demur and talk about economic headwinds.  While being at the top of the Am Law 100 is obviously what many, if not all, firms strive for, merely being included can be a tremendous achievement.  Though admittedly, It is rare to see such rejoicing when ranked 87th in anything — the inverse of Ricky Bobby’s famed axiom.



Unlike the more black box nature of law school rankings, the Am Law 100 is rather straightforward, sorting firms based on [gross revenue](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/04/23/the-2019-am-law-100-gross-revenue/) and [profits per equity partner](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/04/23/the-2019-am-law-100-profits-per-equity-partner/) (PEP) while also collecting the data on [revenue and profits per lawyer](https://www.law.com/2019/04/23/what-helps-the-super-rich-maintain-their-success/).  While it is plausible that some manipulation can take place by limiting the number of equity partners, such a practice is unlikely considering the amount of money those non-equity partners would be losing as well as the simple fact that the Am Law 100 lacks the ubiquity of its law school ranking counterparts, where manipulation can be rampant.[[1]](#_ftn1)

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
So how is this relevant for law students or practicing attorneys seeking to make a change?  As I have [previously written](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/everything-you-need-to-know-about-fall-recruiting-season-part-i/), when law students gear up for the “Fall” (it really starts in July, if not earlier) interview cycle, researching various employers is a necessary method of not only standing out in an interview but also beginning to determine which employer might be the best destination.  The Am Law 100, and its soon to be released Am Law 200 counterpart, can be part of that research effort, along with a litany of other sources including Above the Law’s own [law firm rankings](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firm-rankings/top-law-firms/).

So, what should one focus on?  Gross revenue gives you a sense of the largest players in the Biglaw game.  As someone who graduated law school in the midst of the Great Recession, I am always wary of the economic cycle, knowing that a down turn will eventually come and it will likely have at least some impact on legal employment.  With revenues over $3 billion, it is hard to believe that Kirkland & Ellis (#1 in Gross Revenue) and Latham & Watkins (#2) are going to be in dire straits during the next recession, though a look at the two firms’ debt levels would assuage any lingering doubts.  It is also doubtful that those members of the three-comma club are going to be fail to pay market salaries or bonuses to their attorneys.


But it is not just overall numbers that are worth examining.  Year-over-year revenue changes can provide a sense as to firms that are flourishing and those that while not necessarily floundering, perhaps should be looked at with a bit more caution by prospective candidates.  The ability of Nelson Mullins to increase their gross revenue by 27.5 percent should make any candidate, be it entry-level of lateral, excited about the future of the firm.  The 7.3 percent revenue drop for Baker Botts, sending it from 50th in the Gross Revenue rankings last year to 58th this time around, could be potentially worrisome.

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
While Gross Revenue figures can tell you part of the story with regards to economic health and vitality in Biglaw, it does not tell the whole story.  Perhaps a better metric is PEP.  To understand why, think about international economics for a moment.  The simplest way to measure the relative economic strength of various countries is to look at their Gross Domestic Product (GDP).  Not surprisingly, per the [World Bank’s 2017 figures](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ny.gdp.mktp.cd?view=map&year_high_desc=true), the countries with the two largest economies are the United States and China.  But those countries are home, respectively, to the thirdlargest and the largest populations in the world.  Having a large economy makes sense if you have a lot of people.  A better metric is GDP per capita. The World Bank shows Germany and India as having the fourth and fifth largest economies in the world, as measured by GDP.  However, India has more than 16 times the population of Germany.  So Germany’s [per capita GDP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita) is $50,715 while India’s is $7,056.  It is clear which country’s residents have the higher standard of living.

How does this apply to Biglaw?  Well, BakerMcKenzie sits at third in the Gross Revenue rankings, but they also have 4,720 attorneys firm wide.  With that big of a firm, they better have a lot of revenue coming in the door to deal with what has to be remarkably high overhead.  PEP provides us with the Biglaw equivalent of GDP per capita.  When looking at these numbers, the biggest takeaway is the sheer dominance of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.  With a PEP of $6.53 million, the gap between Wachtell and second place Kirkland at $5.037 million is the roughly same as the gap between Kirkland and #12 Latham at $3.452 million.  To borrow an analogy, Wachtell is playing a different sport than the rest of Biglaw, which probably helps explains its famed compensation structure that can see associates rake in bonuses that are 100 percen of their base salary.  Wachtell’s dominance is not limited to PEP; their revenue per lawyer this past year was $3.207 million.  Second place is Sullivan & Cromwell at $1.739 million, while 25th place is Goodwin Proctor at $1.255 million.  The gap between Wachtell and the #2 firm in revenue per lawyer is MORE THAN TRIPLE the gap between #2 and #25.  That’s absurd.  The obvious takeaway is that if you want to make as much money as possible in the practice of law, try to get a job at Wachtell.  Though that’s [easier said than done](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/the-key-to-wachtells-success-how-they-pay-their-partners/).

Outside the revenue figures, the Am Law 100 also contains some [interesting nuggets](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/04/23/the-2019-am-law-100-by-the-numbers/) which can provide some insight, or at least a healthy chuckle.  For example, someone at Fox Rothschild claimed to have billed 4,200 hours last year, which is either what I will call some creative billing or evidence that robots truly have started taking over the associate ranks.  While 4,000+ billable hours is unique and thus not a particularly valuable data point for job seekers, the fact that Fish & Richardson clocked in with the highest billable hours per lawyer at 1,916 is worth knowing.  On the one hand, it is often better to be busy than slow at a law firm if you are concerned about your long-term job security.  On the other hand, 2,000 billable hours is target throughout much of Biglaw for associates to ensure a bonus.  If that’s the average at a firm you are considering, be prepared for a lot of long nights and weekends.

The Am Law 100 provides a valuable service by crunching the numbers and showing readers how various law firms stack up financially, benefiting not only the curious amongst us but also those who seek to make an informed employment decision.

[[1]](#_ftnref1) See, e.g., U.S. News measures law school expenditures not on a per-student basis, but on a per J.D. student basis.  Thus, hypothetically, schools can use non-J.D. students as veritable ATMs, pumping money into the school via tuition, which is then spent by the school, but never counting toward the denominator of the expenditure equation.

# If It Isn’t One Thing, It’s Another
## As we start year two of what has been an unreal world for all of us, we need to take stock of who we are, who we were, and even perhaps who we hope to be.
By [Jill Switzer](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jillswitzer/)  
onMarch 4, 2021 at 1:44 PMMarch 4, 2021 at 12:08 PM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/if-it-isnt-one-thing-its-another/&text=If%20It%20Isn’t%20One%20Thing,%20It’s%20Another)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/if-it-isnt-one-thing-its-another/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/if-it-isnt-one-thing-its-another/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Literally right on the heels of the remote February bar exam comes the announcement that the California bar exam will be [held remotely in July](http://www.calbar.ca.gov/Admissions/Examinations/California-Bar-Examination/July-2021-California-Bar-Exam).   Hopefully, there will be no recurrence of the ridiculous overreach of the October 2020 exam, in which the examiners claimed that a third of the test takers cheated, and it was up to them to prove they didn’t. How easy is it to prove a negative? I’d ask how much further down the rabbit hole of absurdity the bar exam can go, but I don’t want Joe Patrice to answer the question.

I do have a solution to the “what can I bring to the bar exam” question. How about women can only take the bar exam when they’re past menopause? Ridiculous? Of course, this will eliminate all the patronizing state by state proclamations as to what women examinees can or cannot bring with them. Menstrual products? These arbitrary rules set down by bar examiners, should be dumped in the trash, just like every other stupid and discriminatory rule against women. Is it necessary that the ABA weigh in on this issue? It is way beyond the time to drive a stake in the heart of these [stupid and arcane rules](https://www.abajournal.com/news/article/tampons-and-pads-shouldnt-be-prohibited-at-bar-exam-aba-house-says?). Just imagine what the male late night TV hosts could do with this story.

And as for the male examinees, they also don’t have a walk in the park at bar exam time.  Is having to pee in a bottle really a good idea, a better idea, than being able to use the restroom and wash hands, which we have all been told to do ad nauseam during this past year? At least peeing into a bottle is better than the lack of choices that women have. Hand wipes and hand sanitizers are probably also a violation of something. People who are going to cheat will find a way to do so, and it’s insulting to most examinees who do the right thing.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
These ridiculous policies are on a par with the “no more lawyer jokes” that the then president of the State Bar of California put forth 30 years or so ago.  Jay Leno, then host of the Tonight Show, mocked him mercilessly. Which is worse: being made fun of or taking the lead in not taking yourself too seriously?  You decide, but I have always thought that it’s better to be in control than not, and isn’t that one reason why all of us overachievers became lawyers?

Do you suffer from Zoom fatigue? I do, especially after I have had three or four Zoom calls in a single day. Fatigued in body and mind, these calls, which were once a novelty are now front and center in everyone’s life. I long for the days of phone calls. Yes, I know that I can turn off the video, but if I am the only one doing so, it feels a little strange. Phone calls are so much simpler and easier … no Power Point deck to look at, no checking out others to see if they are doing the same things I am doing (e.g., reading emails, drafting documents, etc.) I plead nolo.

The author of a paper on Zoom fatigue calls out four things: extended eye contact (do your eyes water?), more effort is needed when nodding and other nonverbal signals, the Hollywood Squares (remember that quiz show?) screen is unnatural, and my personal pet peeve: we can’t move around, which is why I bought a new seat cushion and lumbar back support. Clearly [business expenses](https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/25/zoom-fatigue-why-we-have-it-how-to-fix-it.html). He suggests some easy fixes. Since we don’t know how long WFH will continue or whether it will be back to the office at some point yet to be determined, now is as good a time as any to try them out.

For dinosaur lawyers in the Third Circuit, there may be a glimmer of hope. A 70-year-old orthopedic surgeon, who was sacked after a hospital merger, sued for age discrimination, and alleged, among other things, that his replacements were “significantly younger” and less qualified. The surgeon had several months of surgeries already booked at the time of firing. Naturally, the employer moved to dismiss, but the Third Circuit said, “not so fast.” The court found that the plaintiff had adequately pleaded age discrimination and that the issue of “significantly younger” was [a factual issue](https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=8669755418737050172&hl=en&as_sdt=6&as_vis=1&oi=scholarr) awaiting discovery.

Ageism is still rampant. As a former employment lawyer, I understand the need for succession planning and the need to make room for succeeding generations. However, many dinosaurs still have a lot to contribute, and not just in billable hours. There must be some ways to make room for the older and the younger. Does anyone think that “resistant to change” is code for ageism?

Finally, as we start year two of what has been an unreal world for all of us, we need to take stock of who we are, who we were, and even perhaps who we hope to be.

The past year has shown us many things, among which is that we are not our jobs. Our profession, our jobs, are ways to support ourselves and those we care about, those who need our help, but our identities need to be more than just being lawyers. We are parents, sons and daughters, mentors, friends, volunteers, artists, writers, gamers, and the list goes on and on. We need to make sure that we discern the difference between work and the rest of our lives, and who we are as people, and not just as faces on a Zoom screen.

The last year has thrown a curveball (or a slider or fastball or sinker) into the whole [concept of work-life balance](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/06/style/work-life-balance-tips-pandemic.html?campaign_id=33&emc=edit_sl_20210301&instance_id=27588&nl=smarter-living&regi_id=78061995&segment_id=52544&te=1&user_id=0d22f8d038b2fef3184a5c3bba481c1c). It’s up to us to determine how we hit the pitch or strike out.

She’s had a diverse legal career, including stints as a deputy district attorney, a solo practice, and several senior in-house gigs. She now mediates full-time, which gives her the opportunity to see dinosaurs, millennials, and those in-between interact — it’s not always civil. # Have Biglaw Firms Pressed ‘Pause’ On Diversity Initiatives Thanks To Anti-DEI Lawsuits?
## Do these lawsuits have Biglaw firms running scared when it comes to diversity?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 15, 2023 at 2:48 PMSeptember 15, 2023 at 1:56 PM
16
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/have-biglaw-firms-pressed-pause-on-diversity-initiatives-thanks-to-anti-dei-lawsuits/&text=Have%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Pressed%20‘Pause’%20On%20Diversity%20Initiatives%20Thanks%20To%20Anti-DEI%20Lawsuits?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/have-biglaw-firms-pressed-pause-on-diversity-initiatives-thanks-to-anti-dei-lawsuits/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/have-biglaw-firms-pressed-pause-on-diversity-initiatives-thanks-to-anti-dei-lawsuits/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Not so much this image.

Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

Firms are waiting to see if more lawsuits are filed. There seems to be a pause on many of the efforts firms were engaged in—even efforts that pose no risk. It might be because firm leaders are having to spend a disproportionate amount of time on this.

— Joelle Emerson, co-founder and CEO of DEI consultancy Paradigm, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/09/14/blum-lawsuits-stress-test-law-firms-dei-commitment-execution/) on the waiting game Biglaw firms seem to be playing when it comes to their diversity initiatives. The “pause” Emerson speaks of comes in the wake of [lawsuits filed](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/two-biglaw-firms-sued-over-diversity-initiatives/) by conservative legal activist Edward Blum against Morrison & Foerster and Perkins Coie related to their diversity fellowship programs. MoFo has already [changed the language in its application](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/biglaw-caves-morrison-foerster-changes-diversity-fellowship-criteria-following-lawsuit/), as has Gibson Dunn, even though the latter firm [hadn’t been targeted](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/gibson-dunn-second-biglaw-firm-to-cower-from-threatened-affirmative-action-suit/) by Blum.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [DEI](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/dei/), [Diversity](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/diversity/), [Diversity Equity And Inclusion](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/diversity-equity-and-inclusion/), [Edward Blum](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/edward-blum/), [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/)

# Ask A Legal Recruiter: Is It Weird If You Take A Vacation 3 Months After Lateraling?
## How long does the typical hire process take after an offer? And how do you go from Big4 to Biglaw?
By [KINNEY RECRUITING](https://www.kinneyrecruiting.com/)  
onSeptember 20, 2022 at 2:44 PMOctober 11, 2022 at 12:31 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/ask-a-legal-recruiter-is-it-weird-if-you-take-a-vacation-3-months-after-lateraling/&text=Ask%20A%20Legal%20Recruiter:%20Is%20It%20Weird%20If%20You%20Take%20A%20Vacation%203%20Months%20After%20Lateraling?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/ask-a-legal-recruiter-is-it-weird-if-you-take-a-vacation-3-months-after-lateraling/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/ask-a-legal-recruiter-is-it-weird-if-you-take-a-vacation-3-months-after-lateraling/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
For almost two decades, [Kinney Recruiting](https://www.kinneyrecruiting.com/) has been a top international legal recruitment agency and home to some of the most distinguished legal recruiters in the world. With vast market experience and our trademark “no BS” approach, Kinney’s recruiters are favorites among candidates and clients in the legal industry. We are keen to share some of what we have learned with more people, so we have launched [Ask a Legal Recruiter](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ask-a-legal-recruiter/), an opportunity for our recruiters to answer your questions. Do you want to know more about how legal recruiting works or what lateraling looks like? How about our take on the market? If you have a question, email [askarecruiter@kinneyrecruiting.com](mailto:askarecruiter@kinneyrecruiting.com) and we will get back to you with our take!!

Question: “Would it be weird to take a vacation 3 months after lateraling?”

[Daniel Roark](https://www.kinneyrecruiting.com/recruiters/daniel-roark/): This is a very common situation for lateraling candidates and one where an experienced recruiter will assist their candidates by either backchanneling with a firm’s recruiting department/hiring attorney(s) and/or coaching a candidate on the proper timing and manner for discussing such scheduled items post-start date. Should a candidate discuss their booked trip to Tulum in a first interview? Definitely not. But as the contours of an offer for employment and related timing considerations take shape, discussions of a candidate’s schedule should occur. For example, I just represented a candidate for an in-house position who had a long-planned trip to France scheduled for one month after the client’s suggested start date. During the offer stage, I was able to discuss my candidate’s planned vacation with the client, and we reached an efficient solution where the candidate would start as soon as possible (after providing notice) in order to get moved, situated, and trained prior to departing for his vacation. Issues regarding schedules (planned holidays, weddings, medical issues, life events) are commonplace and generally resolved favorably when dealing with reasonable parties who are willing to compromise on some level.

Question: “How long does the typical hire process take after the offer? Including background check, conflicts, etc.”

[Joshua Shirley](https://www.kinneyrecruiting.com/recruiters/joshua-shirley/): Typically, after a Biglaw offer is made and it is accepted, the process takes about 3 weeks for background checks and conflicts to clear. In some cases, it can be longer for laterals who need to have background checks cleared in other countries. Some firms can complete conflicts in under two weeks. Conflicts can also take longer, think 4-7 weeks, during extremely busy periods of lateral movement in the market. These processes typically go quicker and smoother when you’re working with someone who is experienced in guiding attorneys through them. With Kinney’s collective experience, we’ve seen it all and know what works best and what doesn’t.

Question: “How do I go from Big4 to a law firm?”

[Jack Hopper](https://www.kinneyrecruiting.com/recruiters/jack-p-hopper/): The answer largely depends on what kind of work a candidate wants to do with a law firm. If they want to stay strictly in tax, the transition can be more fluid, although still not easy. If the desire is to join an M&A practice for instance, then gaining tax experience in the M&A context is obviously helpful. It is also important to have realistic expectations. Going from Big4 to Biglaw is very difficult without prior law firm experience, and of course you must have an impeccable academic pedigree as well. Targeting smaller regional firms and boutiques can offer more opportunities, particularly for those candidates with strong academics. This way you can start gaining law firm experience and can move up to Biglaw once you have gained said experience.

[Daniel Roark](https://www.kinneyrecruiting.com/recruiters/daniel-roark/): My esteemed colleague, Jack, has correctly framed some of the challenges in transitioning from Big4 to Biglaw. For candidates who hold Tax LLMs and have accrued some transactional tax experience, this lateral option is the most available. For all, much will depend on the state of the hiring market at the time. In 2020 and 2021 when Am Law 100 firms were luring corporate associates with up to six-figure signing bonuses, we were successful in placing candidates with more non-traditional background (i.e., candidates not practicing Biglaw) in regional or major firm roles. Often these candidates were more junior in their careers and required to take steps back in class year to accommodate such a lateral move. For more senior candidates, the way into a law firm is through provable and portable client relationships. Business Development is critical and if you can help a law firm grow its revenue, your candidacy is viewed with favor.

Email [askarecruiter@kinneyrecruiting.com](mailto:askarecruiter@kinneyrecruiting.com) and we will get back to you with our take!

# Morning Docket: 04.30.19
## * Rod Rosenstein is heading to the job market. I'm available to consult if Rod needs some résumé polishing tips. [[National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/2019/04/29/read-rod-rosensteins-resignation-letter/)] * Legal employment numbers are up! That's... not actually great news. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/2019/04/29/law-class-of-2018-notches-highest-legal-employment-rate-in-a-decade/)] * If you were trying to draw up the most glaring gender bias suit, you'd probably pass on "female general counsel asked to serve the men cake" as too far-fetched and yet here we are. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1154314/female-gc-told-to-serve-men-cake-20m-bias-suit-says)] * If you're looking for more insight into the Am Law 100 numbers, the folks you brought them to you will be having an in-depth discussion on the topic all day today. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/04/29/a-live-discussion-about-the-am-law-100/)] * Trump's suing to block congressional subpoenas of his banks because he really, really, doesn't want people to know he's not a billionaire. [[Huffington Post](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/trump-trump-family-sues-deutsche-bank_n_5cc7b0e0e4b07c9a4ce8110e)] * The Seventh Circuit says death by autoerotic asphyxiation isn't accidental. In case, you know, you were planning something in Chicago. [[Courthouse News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/%EF%BB%BFautoerotic-asphyxia-death-wasnt-accidental-7th-circuit-says/)] * Tech giants are trying to gut California's privacy law. [[WIRED](https://www.wired.com/story/california-privacy-law-tech-lobby-bills-weaken/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 30, 2019 at 8:44 AM

# Kirkland & Ellis Hires Paul Clement, Viet Dinh -- And All Of Bancroft's Lawyers!
## Whoa -- this is some big Biglaw news!
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onSeptember 12, 2016 at 1:54 PMSeptember 29, 2016 at 12:50 PM
33
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/kirkland-ellis-hires-paul-clement-viet-dinh-and-all-of-bancrofts-lawyers/&text=Kirkland%20&%20Ellis%20Hires%20Paul%20Clement,%20Viet%20Dinh%20—%20And%20All%20Of%20Bancroft’s%20Lawyers!)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/kirkland-ellis-hires-paul-clement-viet-dinh-and-all-of-bancrofts-lawyers/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/kirkland-ellis-hires-paul-clement-viet-dinh-and-all-of-bancrofts-lawyers/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Ahoy, Kirkland & Ellis!

Huge news in the world of law firm lateral moves: [Kirkland & Ellis](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/kirkland-ellis/), one of Biglaw’s biggest and best names, has hired former U.S. solicitor general Paul Clement, former assistant attorney general Viet Dinh, and all of Clement and Dinh’s colleagues at the elite boutique of [Bancroft PLLC](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/bancroft-pllc/). Wow!

From the [K&E press release](https://www.kirkland.com/sitecontent.cfm?contentID=230&itemId=12393):

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Kirkland & Ellis LLP is pleased to announce that Paul D. Clement, former U.S. Solicitor General and top U.S. Supreme Court and appellate lawyer, will join the Firm as a partner in the Washington, D.C., office. Mr. Clement is currently a partner of Bancroft PLLC, a top appellate litigation boutique in Washington, D.C., founded by Viet D. Dinh, former U.S. Assistant Attorney General for Legal Policy. Mr. Dinh and all of Bancroft’s 15 other attorneys, including Chris Bartolomucci, Erin Murphy, George Hicks and Jeff Harris, will also join Kirkland with Mr. Clement by Oct. 1, in time for the new Supreme Court Term.

Returning to Biglaw is a homecoming of sorts for Paul Clement. Recall that he was at King & Spalding for a short stint after serving as solicitor general, before he [left for Bancroft](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/04/paul-clement-quits-king-spalding-after-ks-moves-to-drop-doma-defense/) in 2011, amid the controversy surrounding his defense of the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA).

Clement was said to earn [$5 million a year](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/04/paul-clement-and-king-spalding-defend-doma-at-a-discount/) at King & Spalding. His pay at Kirkland — one of Biglaw’s most lucrative firms, with average profits per partner of $3.6 million, #5 in the [Am Law 100](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/the-2016-am-law-100-trouble-ahead/2/) — should be well into the mid-seven figures. As noted in the K&E press release, the 50-year-old Clement “has argued more Supreme Court cases since 2000 than any lawyer in or out of government,” with more than 80 arguments before SCOTUS.


Viet Dinh

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Viet Dinh — the 48-year-old founder and head of Bancroft, a leading litigator and constitutional law expert, and highly sought-after counselor to America’s top corporations, especially on corporate-governance issues — should also get a huge payday. Launched in 2003, Bancroft has thrived over its 13-year-history, so K&E must have made Dinh and his partners an offer that was simply too good to refuse.

Kirkland is hiring all 17 of Bancroft’s attorneys (including young Supreme Court superstar [Erin Murphy](https://abovethelaw.com/2013/09/a-young-superstar-makes-her-supreme-court-debut/)). This shouldn’t be a surprise; Bancroft is Above the Law’s [top firm by law school pedigree](https://abovethelaw.com/careers/top-litigation-firms-by-law-school-pedigree-2015/), and its lawyers boast pretty much every elite credential under the sun. Per the [press release](https://www.kirkland.com/sitecontent.cfm?contentID=230&itemId=12393):

“The accomplishments of the Bancroft team are amazing, with 120 U.S. Supreme Court arguments, nine Supreme Court clerkships, 17 courts of appeals clerkships, and five Presidential appointments,” added Gene Assaf, a litigation partner and member of Kirkland’s Global Management Executive Committee based in Washington, D.C. “We see immense opportunity in combining forces.”

Note, by the way, that this appears as a technical matter to be a “mass lateral hire” (à la [Morgan Lewis and Bingham](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/11/morgan-lewis-completes-its-conquest-of-bingham-mccutchen/), or [Andrews Kurth and Kenyon & Kenyon](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/is-a-merger-in-the-cards-for-this-troubled-law-firm/)). In other words, it’s not a “law firm merger” per se, even if the final outcome still involves all of Bancroft’s attorneys getting absorbed into Kirkland.

Congratulations to Kirkland on the incredible influx of tremendous talent, and congratulations to Bancroft lawyers on their impressive new home!

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
We expect to receive additional details over the next few hours; refresh this post for the latest. If you have information you’d like to share, please feel free to [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Kirkland%20and%20Bancroft) or text us (646-820-8477). Thanks!

UPDATE (2:10 p.m.): Here’s coverage of the news from [Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/kirkland-ellis-acquires-top-scotus-boutique/) and [Law360](http://www.law360.com/articles/838932).

UPDATE (2:45 p.m.): And here’s the story of [Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2016/09/12/kirkland-acquires-dc-based-boutique-bancroft/?cn=20160912&pt=Newswire&src=EMC-Email&et=editorial&bu=Law.com).

UPDATE (2:55 p.m.): We’re getting positive reactions from our sources at Bancroft, who it seems will all benefit economically from this deal. The senior partners will be paid handsomely, as noted above; the junior partners will have enhanced equity opportunities (making share partner at K&E isn’t easy, but Bancroft has just a handful of equity partners); and Bancroft associates will be paid on the Kirkland pay scale (market salaries and handsome bonuses). Folks are also excited about the synergies between Bancroft’s top-flight appellate and Supreme Court practice and Kirkland’s strong trial practice. We understand that Bancroft support staffers are being invited to join K&E as well.

We hear that the deal came together very quickly, in a matter of weeks. A key player was federal judge turned Kirkland partner [Mark Filip](https://www.kirkland.com/sitecontent.cfm?contentID=220&itemID=9711), who sits on Kirkland’s Global Management Executive Committee. Filip is quoted in the press release: “I’ve known Paul and Viet for over 25 years, and it’s no surprise how successful and respected they are. We welcome them and their talented team to Kirkland.”

How does Filip know Clement and Dinh? They all overlapped at Harvard Law School — Filip and Clement graduated in 1992, Dinh in 1993 — and Filip and Clement [clerked together for the late Justice Scalia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_law_clerks_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States) (October Term 1993). So law students and young lawyers, be nice to your law school classmates and your co-clerks; you never know when those relationships will come in handy.

UPDATE (3:32 p.m.): The response from in-house counsel — i.e., clients — is positive as well. “Quite a snag for Kirkland,” said [Paul Cappuccio](http://www.timewarner.com/company/management/senior-corporate-executives/paul-t-cappuccio), executive vice president and general counsel of Time Warner (and a former K&E partner himself). “Paul is the best. And Kirkland already has [Chris Landau](https://www.kirkland.com/sitecontent.cfm?contentID=220&itemID=8991), who is also a great appellate advocate, so this is quite a combined team.”

UPDATE (5:05 p.m.): Another noteworthy point: this isn’t just Paul Clement’s return to Biglaw, but to Kirkland & Ellis specifically (where he overlapped with Paul Cappuccio). Clement was [an associate at K&E](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Clement) after his SCOTUS clerkship and before he went over to the Senate Judiciary Committee.

UPDATE (6:15 p.m.): Chiming in from the West Coast, former Facebook general counsel and former K&E partner Ted Ullyot, now a [partner at Andreessen Horowitz](https://a16z.com/author/ted-ullyot/), had this to say: “Great move for both Kirkland and Bancroft. Two world-class organizations joining forces.”

UPDATE (9/13/2016, 5:00 p.m.): For more on this news, see my interview with Viet Dinh: [A Closer Look At Kirkland & Ellis’s Pickup Of The Bancroft Lawyers](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/a-closer-look-at-kirkland-elliss-pickup-of-the-bancroft-lawyers/).

[Former Solicitor General and renowned Supreme Court advocate Paul D. Clement and former Assistant Attorney General and Bancroft PLLC founder Viet D. Dinh and entire Bancroft firm to join Kirkland & Ellis](https://www.kirkland.com/sitecontent.cfm?contentID=230&itemId=12393) [Kirkland & Ellis (press release)]

[David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/) is the founder and managing editor of Above the Law and the author of [Supreme Ambitions: A Novel](https://supremeambitions.com/reviews/). You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://twitter.com/DavidLat), [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/davidlat), and [Facebook](http://facebook.com/DavidLat), and you can reach him by email at [dlat@abovethelaw.com](mailto:dlat@abovethelaw.com).

“Beyond Seminole Rock — Or Why What We Think We Know About Administrative Deference May Be Wrong”: Aaron Nielson has [this post](http://yalejreg.com/nc/beyond-seminole-rock-or-why-what-we-think-we-know-about-administrative-deference-may-be-wrong/) at the “Notice & Comment” blog of the Yale Journal on Regulation about his article titled “[Beyond Seminole Rock](http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2821341)” posted today at SSRN.

Circuit Judge [Richard A. Posner](http://www.fjc.gov/servlet/nGetInfo?jid=1922&cid=999&ctype=na&instate=na) wrote the majority opinion. A U.S. District Judge sitting by designation disagreed with the decision and will issue a dissent in due course.

And Brent Johnson of NJ.com has an article headlined “[Christie: N.J. may take sports betting fight to Supreme Court](http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2016/08/christie_nj_may_take_sports_betting_fight_to_supre.html).”

“Ottawa stripped Atlantic Canada of inclusion on Supreme Court with barely a peep; Justin Trudeau’s approach to Canada’s top court shows the problem with putting all our chips on red”: Peter Cowan of CBC News has [this news analysis](http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/supreme-court-appointments-justin-trudeau-policy-atlantic-canada-1.3713759).

Eliza Collins of USA Today reports that “[Ohio Senate candidate sorry for saying Scalia’s death came ‘at a good time.’](http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/08/10/ted-strickland-scalia-death-apology/88523358/)”

And CNN.com reports that “[Ted Strickland apologizes for comments on Scalia’s death](http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/10/politics/strickland-scalia-apology/).”

“Group linked to Carr brothers’ victims pushes to oust Kansas Supreme Court justices; Kansans for Justice launch non-retention campaign”: Jonathan Shorman of The Topeka Capital-Journal has [an article](http://cjonline.com/news/2016-08-10/group-linked-carr-brothers-victims-pushes-oust-kansas-supreme-court-justices) that begins, “A group with ties to victims of the Carr brothers kicked off a push Wednesday to oust several Kansas Supreme Court justices, who they fault for overturning the death sentences of the two men before the U.S. Supreme Court reversed the decision.”

Posted at [8:10 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68290) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“The Supreme Court sends mixed signal on Hurst ruling’s meaning”: Lyle Denniston has [this post](http://blog.constitutioncenter.org/2016/08/the-supreme-court-sends-mixed-signal-on-hurst-rulings-meaning/) today at the “Constitution Daily” blog of the National Constitution Center.

Posted at [7:44 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68289) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“‘Second Amendment People’ Solutions: Trump’s Clinton ‘joke’ was no coincidence; The GOP espouses a right to bear arms whose logical conclusion is political assassination.” Mark Joseph Stern has [this jurisprudence essay](http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2016/08/trump_s_assassination_joke_is_the_logical_endpoint_for_the_gop.html) online today at Slate.

Posted at [7:40 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68288) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“[Pa.] Superior Court Should Lift Ban on Citing Its Unpublished Opinions”: Yesterday’s edition of [The Legal Intelligencer](http://www.thelegalintelligencer.com), Philadelphia’s daily newspaper for lawyers, contained [this month’s installment](https://t.co/G132j71xVB) of my “Upon Further Review” column.

Posted at [5:16 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68287) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Honda: Crashworthiness Jury Instructions Fail in Wake of ‘Tincher.'” Max Mitchell of [The Legal Intelligencer](http://www.thelegalintelligencer.com) has [this report](https://t.co/sHAsMmAQjH) on the case I argued yesterday on behalf of the plaintiffs-appellees before a three-judge panel of the [Pa. Superior Court](http://www.pacourts.us/courts/superior-court/).

You can access online [Honda’s Brief for Appellant](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/pdf/HondaAppellantBriefFiled.pdf), the [Brief for Plaintiffs-Appellees](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/pdf/MartinezAppelleesBriefFiled.pdf), [Honda’s Reply Brief for Appellant](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/pdf/HondaAppellantReplyBrief.pdf), an [amicus brief filed in support of Honda](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/pdf/PLACAmicusCuriaeBrief.pdf), and an [amicus brief filed in support of plaintiffs-appellees](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/pdf/PAJAmicusCuriaeBrief.pdf).

As The Legal Intelligencer’s article explains, earlier this year a unanimous three-judge Pa. Superior Court panel issued [an unpublished opinion](http://www.pacourts.us/assets/opinions/Superior/out/J-A31020-15m.pdf) in Cancelleri v. Ford Motor Co. that rejected many of the very same arguments that Honda is making in its current appeal. As [previously noted here](http://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/010716.html#065089), I also served as appellate counsel for the plaintiffs-appellees in Cancelleri.

Pa. Superior Court Judge [Anne E. Lazaru](http://www.pacourts.us/courts/superior-court/superior-court-judges/judge-anne-e-lazarus)s, in her opinion for the unanimous panel in Cancelleri, [explained](http://www.pacourts.us/assets/opinions/Superior/out/J-A31020-15m.pdf#page=6) that “in crashworthiness cases, the jury is required to determine whether the vehicle was defective in design as well as whether an alternative, safer, and practicable design existed at the time of design that could have been used instead,” thereby complying with the [Pa. Supreme Court](http://www.pacourts.us/courts/supreme-court/)‘s [decision](http://www.pacourts.us/assets/opinions/Supreme/out/j-80-2013mo%20-%201020173292832303.pdf) in Tincher v. Omega Flex, Inc., which issued after jury verdicts in favor of the plaintiffs had issued in both Cancelleri and Martinez.

The Pa. Superior Court’s opinion in Cancelleri also [held](http://www.pacourts.us/assets/opinions/Superior/out/J-A31020-15m.pdf#page=6) that Tincher did not mandate the admission of industry or governmental standards evidence at the defendant’s behest. In June 2016, in [an unpublished opinion](http://www.pacourts.us/assets/opinions/Superior/out/J-A33020-15m%20-%201027095997772776.pdf) issued in Webb v. Volvo Cars, a separate three-judge Pa. Superior Court panel reached the same result, [holding](http://www.pacourts.us/assets/opinions/Superior/out/J-A33020-15m%20-%201027095997772776.pdf#page=16) (in an opinion for the panel written by Pa. Superior Court Judge [Victor P. Stabile](http://www.pacourts.us/courts/superior-court/superior-court-judges/judge-victor-p-stabile)) that Tincher did not mandate the admission of industry or governmental standards evidence.

Perhaps also worth noting, earlier this year the trial court in Tincher itself [denied defendant Omega Flex’s renewed motion for post-trial relief](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/pdf/TincherTrialCtOpinionOnRemand.PDF) on remand from the Pa. Supreme Court, holding that the the Pa. Supreme Court’s ruling did not require a retrial of the case.

Posted at [5:06 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68286) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Petition for rehearing en banc filed in the 9th Circuit’s recent CFAA case, Facebook v. Vachani”: Orin Kerr has [this post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2016/08/10/petition-for-rehearing-en-banc-filed-in-the-9th-circuits-recent-cfaa-case-facebook-v-vachani/) today at “The Volokh Conspiracy.”

Posted at [3:00 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68285) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“The DC Circuit Should Invalidate The Net Worth Sweep Of Fannie/Freddie Assets; A motley collection of procedural objections should not block a long overdue decision”: Law professor [Richard Epstein](https://its.law.nyu.edu/facultyprofiles/index.cfm?fuseaction=profile.overview&personid=26355) has [this post](http://www.forbes.com/sites/richardepstein/2016/08/08/the-dc-circuit-should-invalidate-the-net-worth-sweep-of-fanniefreddie-assets/) at Forbes.com.

Posted at [2:56 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68284) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Trump’s ‘Second Amendment’ Line Is Protected. Barely.” Law professor [Noah Feldman](http://hls.harvard.edu/faculty/directory/10257/Feldman) has [this essay](http://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2016-08-10/trump-s-second-amendment-line-is-protected-barely) online today at Bloomberg View.

Posted at [1:42 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68283) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“The Limited Role of Common Sense in the Obviousness Analysis”: Dennis Crouch has [this post](http://patentlyo.com/patent/2016/08/limited-obviousness-analysis.html) at “Patently-O” about [a ruling](http://www.cafc.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/opinions-orders/15-2073.Opinion.8-8-2016.1.PDF) that the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit](http://www.cafc.uscourts.gov) issued today.

Posted at [1:32 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68282) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“McAllen student who sued over Mexican pledge and flag loses lawsuit”: The San Antonio Express-News had [this report](http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local/article/Judge-dismisses-First-Amendment-suit-over-Mexican-6000259.php) back in January 2015.

And in other earlier coverage, The Monitor of McAllen, Texas reported in January 2015 that “[Mexican pledge suit against McAllen ISD dismissed](http://www.themonitor.com/news/local/mexican-pledge-suit-against-mcallen-isd-dismissed/article_3af5395a-99ee-11e4-b40f-4383c4ed5e83.html).”

Yesterday, a unanimous three-judge panel of the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit](http://www.ca5.uscourts.gov) issued [this decision](http://www.ca5.uscourts.gov/opinions/pub/15/15-40160-CV0.pdf) affirming the judgment in defendants’ favor.

Posted at [1:20 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68281) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“The University of Chicago Law Review Online Symposium: Presidential Politics and the 113th Justice.” You can access the contents [via this link](http://lawreview.uchicago.edu/page/dialogue).

“11 lawyers apply to fill 2 seats on Arizona’s expanded Supreme Court”: Howard Fischer of The Arizona Daily Star has [an article](http://tucson.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/lawyers-apply-to-fill-seats-on-arizona-s-expanded-supreme/article_1e1d93cf-5427-57e0-acd2-6a67e923e7db.html) that begins, “Eleven lawyers have applied to be one of the two new justices that Gov. Doug Ducey will select for the expanded Arizona Supreme Court.”

“Judge: Glenn Beck must identify sources on Boston Marathon bombing.” Josh Gerstein of Politico.com has [this blog](http://www.politico.com/blogs/under-the-radar/2016/08/glenn-beck-boston-marathon-bombing-226841) post.

Posted at [9:02 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68278) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“We’re beginning to think we have an inkling of Sisyphus’s fate.” So begins [an opinion](http://www.ca10.uscourts.gov/opinions/15/15-4080.pdf) that Circuit Judge [Neil M. Gorsuch](http://www.fjc.gov/servlet/nGetInfo?jid=3125&cid=999&ctype=na&instate=na) released yesterday on behalf of a unanimous three-judge panel of the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit](http://www.ca10.uscourts.gov) representing that Court’s “seventh opinion in the Ute line and still addressing the same arguments we have addressed so many times before.”

Posted at [8:57 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68277) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


In Bashman news from Australia: Yahoo!7 News and the Australian Associated Press combine to report that “[Two thugs bash man unconscious waiting for Melbourne tram](https://au.news.yahoo.com/vic/a/32286866/two-thugs-bash-man-waiting-for-melb-tram/).”

Posted at [8:52 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68276) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Suit: Politics, porn scandal behind changes in Pa. ballot question.” In today’s edition of The Philadelphia Inquirer, Maria Panaritis has [an article](http://www.philly.com/philly/news/politics/20160810_Suit__politics__porn_scandal_behind_changes_in_Pa__ballot_question.html) that begins, “A court filing Tuesday suggested that political motives and concerns over a Supreme Court pornography scandal were behind efforts to alter the wording of a judicial retirement-age ballot question to extend the tenure of Pennsylvania judges to age 75.”

And last Thursday, The Philadelphia Daily News published an editorial titled “[Plan to change retirement age for judges seems shady](http://articles.philly.com/2016-08-04/news/74838707_1_retirement-age-ballot-question-judges).”

You can access the documents filed in the case, including the [Brief for Appellants](http://www.pacourts.us/assets/files/setting-5046/file-5403.pdf) filed yesterday, [via this link](http://www.pacourts.us/news-and-statistics/cases-of-public-interest/sprague-castille-and-zappala-v-cortes).

Posted at [8:46 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2016/08/10/#68275) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

# Morning Docket: 12.20.17
## * Remember when President Trump attacked the federal judiciary, and Neil Gorsuch, then a Supreme Court nominee, called those statements "disheartening" and "demoralizing"? Gorsuch's comments reportedly pissed off the president so much that his SCOTUS nomination was almost rescinded. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-reportedly-considered-rescinding-gorsuchs-nomination/2017/12/18/ad2b3b68-e1c7-11e7-9eb6-e3c7ecfb4638_story.html?utm_term=.b5374f7c629b)] * After passing the GOP's sweeping tax overhaul by a margin of 227-203 yesterday afternoon, the House will need to vote again this morning because several provisions in the bill -- including its name -- violate the Senate's Byrd Rule requirements. [[TIME](http://time.com/5072689/gop-tax-bill-2017-what-is-the-byrd-rule/)] * Under would-be SCOTUS Justice Chief Judge Merrick Garland's leadership, the D.C. Circuit will now live-stream audio of any oral argument upon request. Send your requests by email to liveaudiorequest@cadc.uscourts.gov. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/appeals-court-expands-public-access-to-oral-arguments-with-live-audio-streaming/2017/12/19/748048fe-e4c8-11e7-a65d-1ac0fd7f097e_story.html?utm_term=.da1ee8bd27a5)] * See ya, Sedgwick! Up to 15 partners and up to 65 lawyers and staff members from the failed firm will be headed to Clyde & Co, boosting the British firm's U.S. partnership by one-third. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/sites/americanlawyer/2017/12/18/clydes-hires-15-strong-team-of-us-partners-ahead-of-sedgwick-closure/); [Big Law Business](https://biglawbusiness.com/clyde-co-hires-80-lawyers-and-staff-from-sedgwick/)] * What are the 20 cheapest law schools in the U.S. News Top 100? If you want to do your future finances a favor, you may have to go South. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/12/19/the-20-cheapest-law-schools-in-the-u-s-news-top-100/)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 20, 2017 at 8:33 AMDecember 19, 2017 at 9:31 PM
0

# Dershowitz's Motion To Disqualify Boies Schiller Immediately Dumped For Hilarious Reason
## Swing and a miss.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 13, 2019 at 2:43 PMJune 14, 2019 at 11:18 AM
49
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/dershowitz-harvard-law-school-motion-to-disqualify-boies-schiller-immediately-dumped-for-hilarious-reason/&text=Dershowitz’s%20Motion%20To%20Disqualify%20Boies%20Schiller%20Immediately%20Dumped%20For%20Hilarious%20Reason)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/dershowitz-harvard-law-school-motion-to-disqualify-boies-schiller-immediately-dumped-for-hilarious-reason/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/dershowitz-harvard-law-school-motion-to-disqualify-boies-schiller-immediately-dumped-for-hilarious-reason/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Oops.

Well, that was fast. No sooner did [Alan Dershowitz move to get Boies Schiller removed](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/harvard-law-schools-dershowitz-moves-to-disqualify-boies-schiller-in-sex-trafficking-case/) from the Virginia Guiffre case than the motion dies a fiery — if potentially temporary — death at the stroke of Judge Loretta Preska’s pen.

Apparently, no one on the Harvard Law professor’s side of the table thought to check [Judge Preska’s individual rules](https://freethecourt.files.wordpress.com/2017/03/loretta-a-preska.pdf) (a phenomenon that [seems to be going around](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/plaintiffs-throw-shade-at-jones-day-in-gender-discrimination-lawsuit/?rf=1)), which are quite clear that:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
(a) “For motions other than discovery motions, a pre-motion conference with the court is required before making any motion” and
(b) “Unless prior permission has been granted, memoranda of law in support of and in opposition to motions are limited to 20 pages”

Dershowitz’s filing failed on… both of these counts. Cue the sad trombone.

Undeterred, his attorneys are now asking belatedly for a pre-motion conference to rehash the complaints that Boies Schiller attorneys will be fact witnesses in the case because Dershowitz intends to claim that they’re trying to extort him by representing the plaintiff. Or something like that.

If I were Dershowitz though, I’d be concerned that Judge Preska will allow the motion to go forward without staying the deadline for him to answer or move to dismiss. That’s a deadline that should be coming up and one that he was apparently trying to avoid by bringing this disqualification motion.

# This Biglaw Firm May Demote Partners To Boost Profits
## Which firm is considering shearing the ranks of its equity partners?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 21, 2016 at 11:03 AMSeptember 21, 2016 at 11:04 AM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/this-biglaw-firm-may-demote-partners-to-boost-profits/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Firm%20May%20Demote%20Partners%20To%20Boost%20Profits)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/this-biglaw-firm-may-demote-partners-to-boost-profits/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/this-biglaw-firm-may-demote-partners-to-boost-profits/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Unproductive partners can be a real drain on a Biglaw firm’s profits, and one firm is reportedly searching for a way to take care of its problem in this area. Which firm is considering shearing the ranks of its equity partners?

That would be Shearman & Sterling.

As learned by [Legal Week](http://www.legalweek.com/sites/legalweek/2016/09/20/shearman-sterling-partners-face-profit-share-cut/?slreturn=20160821102329) and confirmed by the [Am Law Daily](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202767897489/Shearman-amp-Sterling-Partners-Face-Possible-Demotions?mcode=0&curindex=0&curpage=ALL), the firm may soon demote some of its equity partners in order to boost its profitability. Shearman global and regional managing partners will likely meet today in New York to discuss the terms of the de-equitizations. It is expected that partners in “less profitable practice areas and regions” will be hit the hardest.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
This is how partners at the firm feel about the situation, according to [Legal Week](http://www.legalweek.com/sites/legalweek/2016/09/20/shearman-sterling-partners-face-profit-share-cut/?slreturn=20160821102329):

“There is a desire within the partnership to make sure that every equity partner is in fact putting in the time and effort and driving the business,” said a current Shearman partner, who requested anonymity in order to speak freely about firm matters.

Another partner said: “It wouldn’t surprise me if Asia or the US were affected by any changes. I don’t think it’s any secret that most firms struggle to make money in Asia unless their partners are on some sort of salaried structure. It’s no secret the firm has struggled with underperforming partners and areas. There are real challenges at the firm.”

Although the firm may be desperate to sack its unproductive partners, Shearman’s partnership agreement requires that a supermajority of 75 percent of equity partners approve a partner’s removal — which is a “major problem for the firm,” per one anonymous partner. If the firm is unable to forcibly remove a partner from equity status, they either can be de-equitized by consent (which we imagine is a rarity), or have their compensation cut by as much as 25 percent annually (yikes!).

Although the firm saw profits per partner fall by 4 percent in 2015, it adopted [Cravath’s new salary scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/biglaw-firm-throws-roving-party-to-announce-pay-raises/) in June. Thus far, demand for legal services in 2016 has been flat, per anonymous firm sources. That being said, it won’t be terribly surprising if Shearman & Sterling culls its herd of equity partners in January. Best of luck, partners.

# Top 50 Biglaw Firm Announces Yet Another Salary Hike For Associates
## More cold, hard cash for associates.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 8, 2022 at 10:34 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/proskauer-cravath-raise-2022/&text=Top%2050%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Announces%20Yet%20Another%20Salary%20Hike%20For%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/proskauer-cravath-raise-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/proskauer-cravath-raise-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw firms are continuing to make it rain Cravath cash, and associates couldn’t be happier about it.

The latest firm to announce a Cravath match is Proskauer Rose, a firm that took in $989,981,000 in 2020 gross revenue, making it No. 43 on the most recently Am Law 100. The firm initially raised salaries to the Davis Polk scale on February 23, and now, less than two weeks later, they’re back again with even more money for their hardworking associates.

Proskauer Rose will be paying associates according to the following grid:



Congratulations once again to everyone at the firm!

(Flip to the next page to read the full memo from Proskauer Rose.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# It May Have Taken 180 Years, But A Woman Is Finally At The Helm Of This Biglaw Firm
## Congratulations are in order.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 29, 2019 at 6:45 PMOctober 29, 2019 at 3:17 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/it-may-have-taken-180-years-but-a-woman-is-finally-at-the-helm-of-this-biglaw-firm/&text=It%20May%20Have%20Taken%20180%20Years,%20But%20A%20Woman%20Is%20Finally%20At%20The%20Helm%20Of%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/it-may-have-taken-180-years-but-a-woman-is-finally-at-the-helm-of-this-biglaw-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/it-may-have-taken-180-years-but-a-woman-is-finally-at-the-helm-of-this-biglaw-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


What Biglaw firm recently announced their new managing partner (effective January 2020) would be a woman for the first time in the firm’s 183-year history?

Hint: The Am Law 200 firm was founded in 1836, and currently has offices in New York; Washington; Los Angeles; Chicago; Stamford; Parsippany; Houston; San Diego; and Brussels.

# Donald Trump Angered By Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Saying She'll Move To Foreign Nation If He's Elected President
## The Notorious RBG has made Donald Trump see red.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 12, 2016 at 3:58 PMMarch 18, 2019 at 9:02 AM
137

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg

Now it’s time for us to move to New Zealand.

— Justice [Ruth Bader Ginsburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruth_Bader_Ginsburg), recounting something her late husband, tax law scholar [Martin Ginsburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_D._Ginsburg), would have said if he’d have been alive to see the day when [Donald Trump](https://www.donaldjtrump.com/) could [potentially be elected as president](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/11/us/politics/ruth-bader-ginsburg-no-fan-of-donald-trump-critiques-latest-term.html). Justice Ginsburg went on to state: “I can’t imagine what this place would be — I can’t imagine what the country would be — with Donald Trump as our president. For the country, it could be four years. For the court, it could be — I don’t even want to contemplate that.” This is the second time that Justice Ginsburg has made [negative public remarks](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/with-the-future-of-scotus-in-mind-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-shudders-at-the-thought-of-a-trump-presidency/) about the possibility of Trump’s election as president.

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  

President Donald Trump?

In response to Justice Ginsburg’s rather inflammatory comments, Trump said the following in a telephone interview earlier today with the [New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/13/us/politics/ruth-bader-ginsburg-donald-trump.html): “I think it’s highly inappropriate that a United States Supreme Court judge gets involved in a political campaign, frankly. I think it’s a disgrace to the court and I think she should apologize to the court. I couldn’t believe it when I saw it. That she should be saying that? It’s so beneath the court for her to be making statements like that. It only energizes my base even more. And I would hope that she would get off the court as soon as possible.”

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is an editor at Above the Law. Feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, or comments. # Join Above The Law In Chicago On May 23!
## Columnist Jon Wolf will lead a discussion of the legal pitfalls in the startup world — and you’re invited!
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onMay 9, 2023 at 3:45 PMMay 16, 2023 at 5:35 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/join-above-the-law-in-chicago-on-may-23/&text=Join%20Above%20The%20Law%20In%20Chicago%20On%20May%2023!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/join-above-the-law-in-chicago-on-may-23/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/join-above-the-law-in-chicago-on-may-23/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[](https://info.abovethelaw.com/legal-tales-from-the-startup-side)We’re pleased to invite you to join Above the Law’s own Jonathan Wolf for “Legal Tales From the Startup Side,” a panel presented by ATL and Thompson Coburn as part of the INVEST 2023 conference in Chicago.

Audience participation is encouraged, and registrants are welcome to stay for post-event networking as well!

Jon will lead a freewheeling discussion of the legal pitfalls facing emerging and high-growth companies in healthcare and life sciences. He’ll be joined by Daniel Tardiff of Thompson Coburn and Matthew Loven of Maslon LLP.

The panel will explore topics including:

- Emerging challenges facing healthcare startups today
- Choosing the right law firm and ensuring it doesn’t overbill
- The relevant regulators and what they will be regulating
- Securing stakeholder buy-in as a strategy for preventing legal liability
- Postmortems on recent healthcare industry fiascos like the Outcome Health case
The panel is scheduled from 5:15-6:15 at the Ritz-Carlton in Chicago, with a networking reception immediately after.

The event is complimentary, but [registration is required](https://info.abovethelaw.com/legal-tales-from-the-startup-side).

INVEST is the nation’s premier conference uniting active investors with corporate business development experts to facilitate investment opportunities with the most promising healthcare startups.

Sponsored by:

[Register Now](https://info.abovethelaw.com/legal-tales-from-the-startup-side)
